Central banks could soon use statistics based on big data to help with their decision-making, as well to evaluate how their decisions affect the financial system. This of course relies on these statistics being of high quality. Read more https://t.co/05FM3yjE6Y https://t.co/B9R1PIclF1

The paper looks at how a search for “autos & vehicles” could provide information on future registrations of new cars in the euro area. It finds that including Google searches increases forecasting accuracy https://t.co/05FM3yjE6Y https://t.co/o8JO3C5n4c

What if Google could be used for economic forecasts? The latest Statistics Paper looks at whether Google searches could provide more timely feedback to policymakers for their decision-making https://t.co/05FM3yjE6Y https://t.co/srT5jH9BC1

ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos will also speak at the conference, focusing on the ways to boost companies’ productivity. The crucial factor in this, he writes in a blog post, is to harness the benefits of digitalisation and artificial intelligence https://t.co/bBzzEGdkk2

Speakers include Executive Board member Peter Praet. In a recent blog post he writes that a well-functioning market for corporate financing is a key component of the monetary transmission mechanism https://t.co/AvK3B5HaTB

How can companies be encouraged to invest in technology? How can firms’ financing conditions be improved? Our joint conference today and tomorrow with @EIB examines these questions and more https://t.co/8uwLJdiKI0 https://t.co/3YDQ89N4St
Monetary developments in the euro area (Oct 2018) https://t.co/Q1Yk7ynUHD

Are you on Instagram? We’re excited to announce that we are too! Follow us for a *snapshot* of what we are up to https://t.co/XbinbForna  📸 https://t.co/0vF9NkfYQ2

Please find Mario Draghi's introductory statement for the ESRB hearing at the European Parliament's ECON committee here https://t.co/KDmprWz62a. Press releases on the new ESRB reports mentioned are here https://t.co/S45mqsm3qC and here https://t.co/9dzMvNdvRs.

Draghi: I am confident that you and the EU leaders will again play an instrumental role in moving this EMU agenda forward, so that we can deliver tangible results to mark the 20th anniversary of the euro
Draghi: If we want to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past, completing the banking union and building an ambitious capital markets union are essential
Draghi: The euro area needs a fiscal instrument to help maintain convergence in the face of large exogenous shocks.

Draghi: If euro area economies had a greater level of resilience, they would also be more likely to react to a common shock in a similar way, thus reducing costly macroeconomic divergences which cannot be addressed by our single monetary policy
Draghi: We need to rekindle faith in our common rules and ensure that they are respected
Draghi: A significant degree of monetary policy stimulus will be maintained, even after the end of net asset purchases
Draghi: The Governing Council continues to anticipate that, subject to incoming data confirming our medium-term inflation outlook, net asset purchases will come to an end in December 2018
Draghi: Overall, recent developments confirm the Governing Council’s earlier assessments of the medium-term inflation outlook
Draghi: A gradual slowdown is normal as expansions mature and growth converges towards its long-run potential. Some of the slowdown may also be temporary.
Draghi at European Parliament: Data that have become available since my last visit in September have been somewhat weaker than expected
Introductory statement Mario Draghi at Hearing of the ECON committee of the European Parliament https://t.co/jHakMjUbN9

Cœuré: Digitalisation is the breeding ground for cyber-threats.
Cœuré: The next financial crisis may well start as a cyber incident.

Highlights der Diskussion beim aktuellen #ECBYouthDialogue mit Studierenden und Absolventen der @FrankfurtSchool sowie den beiden Vorsitzenden der Bankenaufsicht Danièle Nouy und Sabine Lautenschläger hier auch auf Deutsch https://t.co/rJh1YdFYmT 8/ https://t.co/ybdk4zwWti

What did the students and alumni from @FrankfurtSchool think about meeting the heads of European banking supervision? You can also see some photos from our #ECBYouthDialogue here https://t.co/KJhv4Ge6xi 7/ https://t.co/3HEzOWLEca

The students also submitted questions online – many wanted to know if we offer internships. And yes we do! They are advertised year-round, but we also run a special supervision traineeship programme, open for applications in January https://t.co/z3BeiTmXWJ #ECBYouthDialogue 6/ https://t.co/t8aAMmzE7G

We all love Fridays. Especially Sabine Lautenschläger! That’s the day many staff get together for a regular meeting to exchange ideas and experiences. #FridayFeeling https://t.co/gpGSFhLhaV #ECBYouthDialogue 5/ https://t.co/ImiEmVsvHu
When asked how they avoid mistakes, they described the strong trust between them. #FourEyesPrinciple https://t.co/PgYICn71W4 #ECBYouthDialogue 4/ https://t.co/wEojwTgLQg
Danièle Nouy explained that banks expect to receive equal treatment from supervisors. https://t.co/IiPeFNDapN #ECBYouthDialogue 3/ https://t.co/DF3EIRsSX4
They explained how they got ECB Banking Supervision up and running so quickly back in 2014. Read more of the discussion here https://t.co/5OtFdiNfcT 2/ https://t.co/8hjsgAuOWV

(THREAD) At our latest #ECBYouthDialogue, hosted by @FrankfurtSchool, students and alumni met Supervisory Board Chair Danièle Nouy and Vice-Chair Sabine Lautenschläger. They discussed topics such as the main challenges faced & the future of supervision https://t.co/A4xX6dega3 1/ https://t.co/6IdfPsz0aB

The ECB’s annual survey on profitability shows that significant banks expect their profitability to continue to grow slowly over the next three years, in part based on increasing income from lending. Learn more about the results of the survey https://t.co/MikZx5XKbi https://t.co/1exaBtuFwX

The time for banks to put their #Brexit plans into action is drawing near. While significant banks will be supervised directly by the ECB, less significant banks will come under the supervision of national authorities. Find out more https://t.co/gcAvVSA6wb https://t.co/4xtgpypOQY

To absorb unexpected losses, banks are required to hold a minimum amount of capital. They use internal models to reflect their individual risk profile and determine this amount. Learn more about the ECB’s targeted review of internal models https://t.co/zHHlLQgxIm https://t.co/eX1nC6Nbyt

Can non-euro area Member States of the EU participate in the Single Supervisory Mechanism? Find out more about close cooperation as an entryway to the banking union https://t.co/OfYsnvE3Qv https://t.co/iKlqU1z7P2

We asked Danièle Nouy, who ends her five-year term as ECB Supervisory Board Chair this year, to reflect on her career. In this video, she talks about the biggest challenge she has faced as Chair. Read the full interview https://t.co/YwgyIrMk1i https://t.co/EEtwuWycPi
